questions.text: What is the composition of Amsorb?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ca(OH)2, CaCI2, CaSO4 

 

  • Amsorb is a new-generation CO₂ absorbent used in anesthesia circuits.
  • Its composition:
    • Calcium hydroxide [Ca(OH)₂] – main absorbent.
    • Calcium chloride [CaCl₂] – catalyst.
    • Calcium sulfate [CaSO₄] – hardener/stabilizer.
    • Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) – binding agent.
  • Unlike soda lime, Amsorb does not contain strong alkalis (NaOH, KOH, Ba(OH)₂).
  • Therefore, it does not produce toxic by-products like compound A (from sevoflurane degradation) or carbon monoxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca(OH)₂, NaOH, KOH: This is the composition of Soda lime, which contains strong alkalis → risk of compound A and CO formation.

 

Option C. Ca(OH)₂, NaOH, CaCl₂: NaOH is not part of Amsorb.

 

Option D. Ba(OH)₂, CaSO₄: This represents Baralyme, another older absorbent, but associated with fire risk and not used now.

questions.text: A new estrogen receptor agonist is being evaluated for the treatment of postmenopausal symptoms. A prospective study shows that the drug increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in treated women who smoke compared to untreated women who smoke, with a relative risk (RR) of 1.70 and p-value of 0.01. In nonsmokers, no increased risk of DVT is evident with use of the drug (RR = 0.96; p-value = 0.68). Which of the following describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Effect modification

questions.text: RDA of calcium for pregnant and breastfeeding mothers are, respectively:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1000 mg and 1200 mg

 

  • Pregnant mothers require 1000 mg/day to support fetal bone development, while lactating mothers need 1200 mg/day to compensate for calcium lost in breast milk.

 

RDA of Calcium:

 

  • Males, Females and Pregnant ladies = 1000mg/day.
  • Lactating females, Elderly male & female [>60years] = 1200mg/day.

questions.text:
According to NUHM, arrange the following in the correct order as per population covered from highest level to lowest. 

 

  1. Urban Primary Health Centre
  2. Urban Community Health Centre
  3. Auxiliary Nurse Midwife
  4. Urban Social Health Activist
  5. Mahila Arogya Samiti
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 1, 3, 4, 5

 

2. Under NUHM (National Urban Health Mission) the Urban Community Health Centre (UCHC/UCHC-level) is the higher-level facility covering the largest population catchment. It is followed by

 

1. Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) which serves fewer people. 

 

3. Frontline workers like ANMs serve individual households and thus cover smaller populations than PHCs.

 

4. Urban Social Health Activists (USHA/ASHA-equivalent) 

 

5. Mahila Arogya Samitis work at the community/ward level covering still smaller populations.

 

Thus the ordering 2→1→3→4→5 reflects decreasing catchment size.

questions.text: Which of the following peripheral blocks is best for shoulder surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interscalene block

 

  • Interscalene block targets the roots/trunks of the brachial plexus (C5–C7).
  • Provides excellent anesthesia and analgesia for shoulder and proximal humerus surgeries.
  • Advantages: Superior pain control, reduced opioid requirement, and good post-op analgesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infraclavicular block: Targets cords of brachial plexus; better for elbow, forearm, and hand surgery, not ideal for shoulder.

 

Option C. Axillary block: Targets terminal branches; suitable for forearm and hand, inadequate for shoulder.

 

Option D. Supraclavicular block: Targets trunks/divisions; excellent for arm, elbow, forearm, hand, but may spare the suprascapular nerve → incomplete shoulder coverage.

 

Note the following images for position and area distribution of various Brachial Plexus Blocks:

questions.text: What is the size of the endotracheal tube and blade to be used for resuscitation of a preterm neonate with weight 1.8 kg not responding to PPV?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Size 0 blade, 3 mm tube

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy with a known history of atopic dermatitis is brought to the emergency department with worsening facial rash and fever for 2 days. His parents state that he had an eczema flare recently for which they applied an over-the-counter steroid cream. Shortly after, he developed painful vesicles that spread rapidly over the cheeks. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex virus

 

This child with a background of atopic dermatitis who developed rapidly spreading, painful vesicles and fever after steroid use has eczema herpeticum. This is a severe form of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection overlaying compromised skin, often triggered in eczema by topical immunosuppressants. Key features include clustered vesicular lesions, rapid spread, systemic symptoms, and sometimes punched-out erosions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus: MRSA typically causes localized abscesses or impetiginization in atopic skin, presenting as yellowish crusts, not vesicles with rapid coalescence and pain.

 

Option C. Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus: MSSA leads to impetigo or cellulitis, also characterized by honey-colored crusts or erythema, not widespread vesiculobullous lesions as in eczema herpeticum.

 

Option D. Varicella zoster virus: VZV causes chickenpox with lesions in various stages (macule, papule, vesicle) and often involves the trunk and extremities, not limited facial vesicles with atopic history.

choices.text: Knowledge and skills instilled in the minds

questions.text: All of the following apply to health propaganda except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reflective behavior is promoted

 

Propaganda is designed to persuade and often targets emotions and attitudes using selective information; it focuses on dissemination and persuasive messaging rather than fostering critical, reflective decision-making. Therefore promoting reflective (critical) behavior is not a typical aim of propaganda.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knowledge and skills instilled in the minds: Propaganda may convey knowledge or instructions, but often in a biased manner; it can instill actionable skills if designed that way.

 

Option C. Appeals to emotion: A hallmark of propaganda is emotional appeal to influence attitudes and behaviour quickly.

 

Option D. Process is information centered: Propaganda often centres on targeted information (though selective), which drives its messaging strategy.

questions.text: Identify the defective enzyme in a patient whose dibucaine number was 20.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Butyrylcholinesterase

 

Dibucaine number test is used to detect atypical butyrylcholinesterase enzyme activity.

 

Butyrylcholinesterase (pseudocholinesterase, plasma cholinesterase) metabolizes succinylcholine and mivacurium.

 

  • Normal dibucaine number =/>80.
  • Heterozygous atypical enzyme = 40–60.
  • Homozygous atypical enzyme =/<20 → indicates markedly prolonged paralysis after succinylcholine administration.

 

Thus, a dibucaine number of 20 = homozygous abnormal butyrylcholinesterase deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholinesterase: True cholinesterase, located at synapses and RBCs; not related to dibucaine number.

 

Option B. Monoamine oxidase (MAO): Metabolizes monoamines (serotonin, dopamine, norepinephrine); no role in succinylcholine metabolism.

 

Option C. Catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT): Metabolizes catecholamines; unrelated to dibucaine test.

questions.text: A research laboratory develops a new serologic test for detecting prostate cancer. The new assay is compared to biopsy. It is found that the test result is negative in 95% of patients who do not have the disease. If the new assay is used on 8 blood samples taken from patients without prostate cancer, what is the probability of all 8 test results coming back negative?
questions.solution: Ans. D) 0.95 (raised to power 8)

questions.text: Which of the following cylinders can be used in patients with acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma along with oxygen?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Brown

questions.text: The Fernandez reaction of lepromin test is read at:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours 

 

The Fernandez reaction of the lepromin test is an early response characterized by erythema and induration at the injection site, reflecting a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction. It is typically read at 48 hours after intradermal injection of lepromin. This reaction indicates a cell-mediated immune response and is seen mainly in tuberculoid forms of leprosy.

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. 21 Days: The Mitsuda reaction is the late response read at 21 days and reflects granuloma formation and natural resistance to Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text: Which of the following are included in malpighian layer of the epidermis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stratum spinosum and stratum basale

 

The Malpighian layer of the epidermis refers to the stratum basale (germinativum) and the stratum spinosum together. These layers are highly metabolically active, contain mitotically dividing keratinocytes, and are responsible for regeneration of the epidermis. They are rich in desmosomes, which provide mechanical strength and cohesion between keratinocytes. Melanocytes in the basal layer also transfer melanin granules to keratinocytes here, giving pigmentation. Since these layers are vital for proliferation and differentiation, they are considered the “germinative” portion of the epidermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stratum corneum and stratum granulosum: These are superficial non-proliferative layers. Stratum granulosum contains keratohyalin granules. The granulosum contributes mainly to barrier function and water resistance rather than cell proliferation. The stratum corneum is the outermost layer of the epidermis composed of dead, flattened, enucleated keratinocytes known as corneocytes. It serves as the main physical and chemical barrier, preventing water loss (trans-epidermal water loss) and protecting against pathogens, chemicals, and mechanical stress.

 

Option C. Stratum granulosum and stratum lucidum: The stratum lucidum is a thin, translucent layer of the epidermis found only in thick, hairless skin such as the palms and soles. It consists of densely packed, flattened keratinocytes that have lost their nuclei and organelles, appearing clear under the microscope. This layer provides an additional barrier to friction and shear forces, enhancing protection in high-pressure areas.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a vital statistic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dependency ratio

 

Not a vital statistic. It is a demographic measure (ratio of dependents <15 and >64 years to working-age population 15–64 years).

P= population of respective age in brackets mentioned

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Birth rate: Vital statistic. Derived from registered live births in a given population and time.

 

Option B. Fertility rate: Vital statistic. Measures reproductive performance in a population.

 

Option D. Life expectancy at birth: Vital statistic. Derived from mortality data and life tables.

choices.text: Immunoglobulin, followed by vaccine at 6 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following should be administered to the newborn born to a mother found to have HBsAg positive at labour?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Hepatitis B vaccine + Immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 2 month old child comes to the OPD with complaints of fever, pain and fluctuant swelling at the Left upper limb where he recently received a vaccine. Which of the following steps should be done in the treatment of this child?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Incision and drainage

choices.text: The diamond shows the overall pooled results
Each rectangle depicts a single study
The vertical dashed line is the "line of no effect"
The size of the rectangle denotes the sample size

questions.text: Which among the given statements is incorrect regarding the interpretation of these plots?
questions.solution: Ans. C) The vertical dashed line is the "line of no effect"

choices.text: Conduct separate analyses of the 12 nonadherent patients and the 138 adherent patients
﻿Exclude all 12 nonadherent patients from analysis ﻿﻿
Exclude the 3 nonadherent patients in the group taking placebo from analysis
Keep all 12 nonadherent patients in their respective groups for analysis

questions.text: An investigator is conducting a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled intention-to-treat clinical trial of a new drug for the treatment of peripheral neuropathy in adults with multiple myeloma (MM). One hundred fifty patients with MM are enrolled in the trial and randomized to receive either the new drug (n = 75) or placebo (n = 75). Trial protocol requires that patients in both groups take 1 pill per day and keep a pain diary. After 3 months of treatment, each patient is interviewed, and the pain diaries are reviewed; 9 patients taking the new drug and 3 patients taking placebo did not take the pills as instructed. Which of the following best describes how the data pertaining to all patients who did not adhere to protocol should be treated?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Keep all 12 nonadherent patients in their respective groups for analysis

questions.text: A physician is assessing the body composition of patients using various anthropometric indices. Which of the following indices can he measure without height?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Corpulence index

questions.text: Post-dural puncture headache depends on all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Timing of ambulation

 

  • Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) results from persistent CSF leak through the dural puncture site, causing decreased CSF pressure and traction on pain-sensitive structures.
  • Risk factors include:
    • younger age
    • pregnancy
    • female sex
    • large cutting needles 
    • multiple puncture attempts
    • lower BMI.
  • Timing of ambulation does not influence the incidence of PDPH — earlier belief that prolonged supine rest prevents PDPH has been disproven.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age: PDPH is more common in younger patients (<40 years) and less common in elderly due to decreased dural elasticity.

 

Option C. Pregnancy: Pregnant women, especially in late gestation, are more prone because of hormonal and anatomical changes (engorged epidural veins, higher intrathecal pressure).

 

Option D. Type of needle: Larger bore, cutting-edge needles (eg, Quincke) increase PDPH risk; pencil-point splitting needles (eg, Whitacre, Sprotte) reduce incidence.

questions.text: You are planning to wean a patient off mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is not a criterion to do so?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Vital capacity more than 5 ml/kg

choices.text: Detection of VDPV in a case of Acute Flaccid Paralysis
Detection of a single case of wild polio in a person with Acute Flaccid Paralysis
Detection of any cVDPV infected individuals
Detection of wild PV infection in a healthy asymptomatic individual

questions.text: Any of the following should be considered as evidence of an outbreak of polio except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Detection of VDPV in a case of Acute Flaccid Paralysis 

 

  • Outbreak definition (WHO/India Polio Eradication Initiative):
    • A single case of wild poliovirus (WPV) in an AFP patient = outbreak.
    • Any detection of cVDPV (circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus) = outbreak.
    • Detection of WPV in a healthy individual (via contact/environmental surveillance) is also treated as outbreak evidence, because it indicates community circulation.
  • But detection of VDPV (Vaccine Derived Poliovirus, non-circulating, in a single AFP case) is not always considered an outbreak. It may be an isolated case, not yet evidence of circulation. Only when it is cVDPV (circulating, genetically linked in multiple cases or environmental isolates) does it constitute an outbreak.

choices.text: Testosterone low, Dihydrotestosterone low, Estradiol normal
Testosterone high, Dihydrotestosterone low, Estradiol high
Testosterone high, Dihydrotestosterone low, Estradiol low
Testosterone high, Dihydrotestosterone high, Estradiol high

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the OPD to discuss hair loss. He has hair loss primarily around the temples, which began insidiously 3 years ago. Physical examination shows moderate thinning of hair at the anterior scalp, temporal region, and vertex. An oral medication is prescribed to treat the hair loss. After the initiation of therapy, which of the following changes would most likely occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Testosterone high, Dihydrotestosterone low, Estradiol high

 

The patient has androgenetic alopecia (male pattern baldness), which is driven by the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-α reductase. Oral finasteride, a 5-α reductase inhibitor, is commonly prescribed to reduce scalp DHT levels. With treatment, testosterone levels rise because less of it is converted, while DHT levels fall, reducing miniaturization of hair follicles. Some testosterone is also diverted to estradiol via aromatase activity, leading to a mild increase in estradiol levels. This biochemical profile explains why gynecomastia can occur as a side effect of finasteride therapy.

questions.text: An elderly man with Ca pancreas is receiving intravenous opioids for pain management. Which of the following drugs can be safely administered to him because of ceiling effect on respiratory depression?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Buprenorphine

 

  • Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at µ receptors and an antagonist at κ receptors.
  • As a partial µ agonist, it has a ceiling effect on respiratory depression — beyond a certain dose, further respiratory depression does not occur.
  • This makes it safer in elderly patients, cancer pain, and opioid substitution therapy.
  • Additionally, it has long duration of action and is less likely to cause euphoria → lower abuse potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Full µ agonist, no ceiling effect; dose-dependent respiratory depression. Risky in elderly and frail patients.

 

Option C. Fentanyl: Potent full µ agonist; high risk of respiratory depression, especially with IV use. No ceiling effect.

 

Option D. Methadone: Full µ agonist; long-acting, accumulates in tissues, can cause respiratory depression and QT prolongation.

questions.text: Which health program in India would provide financial aid to BPL families to help manage a child with major life-threatening diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rashtriya Arogya Nidhi

 

Provides financial assistance for medical treatment of poor patients with life-threatening diseases, especially children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojana: This scheme was launched to reduce regional imbalances in tertiary healthcare services by setting up AIIMS-like institutions and upgrading medical colleges. It does not provide direct financial support to patients.

 

Option C. Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: This is a training program for healthcare workers, focusing on essential newborn care and resuscitation. It aims at reducing neonatal mortality, not financial assistance.

 

Option D. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram: A child health screening and early intervention service, addressing 4Ds—

 

  1. Defects at birth, 
  2. Deficiencies,
  3. Diseases, and 
  4. Developmental delays including disabilities. It provides screening and referral, not direct treatment funding.

questions.text: The presence of which structure is responsible for infants to be able to breathe simultaneously while suckling milk?
questions.solution: Ans. C) High larynx

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements.

 

  1. Procaine will not require dose readjustment in a case of liver failure
  2. Meta-zoonoses are transmitted biologically by invertebrate vectors 
  3. Gueldels airway is measured from tip of nose to angle of mandible 
  4. Dextran 40 is the best colloid for microvascular expansion
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

choices.text: Stop aspirin and replace with heparin
Stop aspirin and give a platelet transfusion
Stop aspirin on morning of surgery

questions.text: What would be your advice regarding low-dose aspirin before the procedure?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Continue aspirin

choices.text: Increased number of melanocytes are seen
It is associated with xeroderma pigmentosa
It is caused by increased melanin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased number of melanocytes are seen

 

The image shows classic freckles (ephelides), which are small, brown macules seen predominantly in photo-exposed areas, especially on fair skin. The pigmentation is due to increased melanin production in basal keratinocytes, not an increase in the number of melanocytes. Freckles can be associated with certain genetic conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum, and they commonly appear in sun-exposed areas. In freckles, the number of melanocytes remains normal; it is the melanin production that is increased. Increased number of Melanocytes are seen in Lentigenes but their function of melanin production remains normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seen in photoexposed areas: True; freckles are most commonly observed in sun-exposed regions such as the face, arms, and shoulders.

 

Option C. It is associated with xeroderma pigmentosa: True; freckles (and lentigines) are commonly seen in patients with xeroderma pigmentosum due to their extreme sun sensitivity.

 

Option D. It is caused by increased melanin: True; freckles result from increased melanin synthesis and transfer to nearby keratinocytes, not from increased melanocyte numbers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a measure of position?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Range

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Humidity of air

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to compare Kaplan Meir survival curves?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Friedmann test

questions.text: In the context of Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, which of the following factors does not affect the genetic equilibrium of a population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Random mating

 

  • The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium assumes that certain conditions are met for a population to maintain genetic stability. 
  • These conditions include no mutations, no migration, a large population size, random mating, and no natural selection. 
  • Random mating does not disrupt equilibrium; in fact, it is one of the assumptions of the Hardy-Weinberg model. 
  • However, factors such as small population size (leading to genetic drift), mutations, and gene outflow (migration) can disrupt the equilibrium and change allele frequencies in a population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small population: A small population violates the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium by increasing the effects of genetic drift, which can cause random changes in allele frequencies, leading to a departure from equilibrium.

 

Option C. Mutations: Mutations introduce new genetic variations and can alter allele frequencies, thus disrupting Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

 

Option D. Gene outflow: Gene outflow, or migration (the movement of individuals or their genetic material into or out of a population), alters allele frequencies by introducing or removing genes, disrupting equilibrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Random mating is a condition required for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, and does not affect genetic equilibrium, unlike factors such as small population size, mutations, and gene outflow.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements?

 

1. Rabies is an example of amphixenosis 

2. A disease whose pathogenic response is higher in children compared in adults is defined as hyperendemic disease

3. Aeration tank is the heart of the activated sludge process

4. Multiple tube method is done for detecting the presence of coliform organisms in a sample of water
questions.solution: Ans. C) 3, 4

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is evaluated for a skin rash involving his hands, feet, and scalp for the last 2 weeks. The rash is mildly pruritic and has progressively worsened. The patient has a history of HIV and is not adherent with antiretroviral therapy. Skin examination shows erythematous patches with scales and crusting. Biopsy of the rash as shown below.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Topical permethrin

 

The biopsy image shows mites, eggs, and scybala (fecal pellets) within the stratum corneum, diagnostic of scabies. Immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV, may develop crusted (Norwegian) scabies—severe, widespread, highly contagious, with thick crusts containing large numbers of mites. The first-line treatment is topical permethrin, a scabicidal agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic acyclovir: Used to treat herpesvirus infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster, not parasitic infestations like scabies.

 

Option B. Systemic terbinafine: This antifungal is effective against dermatophyte infections (tinea) but not for mite infestations.

 

Option C. Topical glucocorticoid: Reduces inflammation in various skin disorders but would worsen scabies by suppressing local immunity and aiding mite proliferation.

questions.text: All of the following result in an exacerbation of acne, except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Azelaic acid

choices.text: Duration can be prolonged using an inlaying catheter

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of epidural over spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Duration can be prolonged using an inlaying catheter

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of acute eczema?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Intercellular edema

questions.text: Which of the following is not an organophosphate insecticide?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DDT

 

DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is an organochlorine insecticide, not an organophosphate. Organophosphates (like fenthion, malathion, diazinon) act by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase; DDT works via prolonged sodium channel activation and has different chemical class and toxicological profile. DDT is historically used in vector control but is distinct chemically and in regulatory considerations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fenthion: Fenthion is an organophosphate insecticide that inhibits acetylcholinesterase and is used for agricultural and vector control; it belongs to the correct class.

 

Option C. Malathion: Malathion is a widely used organophosphate insecticide/larvicide and acts by cholinesterase inhibition — it is correctly an organophosphate.

 

Option D. Diazinon: Diazinon is also an organophosphate insecticide with acetylcholinesterase-inhibiting action — thus not the odd one out.

questions.text: A study calculated the correlation coefficient between smoking and lung cancer incidence as 1.4. What does this result indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mistake in calculation

 

  • The correlation coefficient (r) ranges from -1 to +1, where +1 indicates a perfect positive correlation, -1 indicates a perfect negative correlation, and 0 indicates no correlation. 
  • A value of 1.4 is outside this range, meaning an error must have occurred in the calculation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Correlation coefficients must fall between -1 and +1. A value outside this range, such as 1.4, suggests a calculation error.

choices.text: The states with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1 are in the elimination phase
NPU is the best for protein quality
Standardisation is done before comparing the mortality rates of two countries due to difference in number of deaths
Perflation ventilation is a type of mechanical ventilation

questions.text: Identify the correct statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The states with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1 are in the elimination phase

 

Annual Parasite Incidence (API) is an important epidemiological indicator for malaria. According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016–2030), a state can be considered in the elimination phase if the API is less than 1 and all districts within that state also report API <1. This ensures transmission is uniformly controlled and not just limited to selected areas. Achieving and maintaining API <1 across all districts is a prerequisite before declaring malaria elimination status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NPU is the best for protein quality: This is incorrect. Biological Value (BV) is considered the best index for protein quality, not Net Protein Utilization (NPU). BV measures how efficiently dietary protein is converted into body proteins. Biological Value = [retained Nitrogen/Absorbed nitrogen] x 100

 

Option C. Standardisation is done before comparing the mortality rates of two countries due to difference in number of deaths: Wrong because standardization corrects for differences in age structure of populations, not just the number of deaths. Crude mortality rates may be misleading if age distributions differ.

 

Option D. Perflation ventilation is a type of mechanical ventilation: Incorrect. There is no such type of ventilation called perflation ventilation. Recognized types include volume-controlled, pressure-controlled, high-frequency, etc. This option is a distractor.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of an interview in the correct order in a sequence.

 

1. Starting an interview

2. Encouragement

3. Establishing contact

4. Securing rapport
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3-1-4-2

 

First establish contact (3) — initial greeting and introductions — which opens the interaction. 

 

 

Then start the interview (1) by stating purpose and agenda. 

 

 

Next secure rapport (4) through empathy, appropriate nonverbal cues, and trust-building.

 

 

Finally provide encouragement (2) during the interview to elicit information and maintain dialogue.

 

This sequence supports a logical, patient-centred interview flow.

questions.text:
Arrange the following corticosteroids in the order of increasing t1/2 (low to high).

 

1. Dexamethasone

2. Hydrocortisone

3. Betamethasone 

4. Prednisolone
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4, 1, 3 

 

The order of increasing half-life from low to high is:
Hydrocortisone < Prednisolone < Dexamethasone < Betamethasone

 

The biological half-life (duration of glucocorticoid effect) of these corticosteroids generally increases in the order:

 

  • Hydrocortisone (short-acting): half-life approx 8-12 hours
  • Prednisolone (intermediate-acting): half-life approx 12-36 hours
  • Dexamethasone (long-acting): half-life approx 36-54 hours
  • Betamethasone (long-acting): half-life approx 36-54 hours

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of a healed forehead laceration. On examination, the scar is pink, firm, and mildly raised, without surrounding erythema or edema; it does not extend beyond the initial wound borders. The patient is reassured that the scar should flatten over the following months. The process by which this occurs relies mostly on enhanced cellular production of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metalloproteinases

 

The patient has a hypertrophic scar, which stays within the original wound boundaries and often remodels over time. Scar maturation and remodeling are primarily mediated by matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), which degrade excess collagen and extracellular matrix components. This breakdown allows realignment of collagen fibers and scar flattening. Balanced activity of MMPs and tissue inhibitors ensures normal healing, while excessive or deficient activity can result in abnormal scars. Over time, the raised scar should soften and flatten as collagen remodeling continues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasminogen activator: This enzyme converts plasminogen into plasmin, which plays a role in fibrinolysis and clot breakdown during the early wound healing phase. It places important role in debridement of fibrin clots, not Collagen Remodelling of Scar

 

Option C. Reactive oxygen species: ROS are produced by neutrophils and macrophages during the inflammatory phase of wound healing. They help kill pathogens and signal repair but excessive ROS cause tissue damage. They are not directly involved in collagen remodeling of scars.

 

Option D. Tumor necrosis factor-alpha: TNF-α is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that drives the initial immune response and promotes angiogenesis during early healing. Its role diminishes as healing progresses.

questions.text: Out of a family of 4 members, one of them developed influenza infection. Four days later, 2 other members developed the same. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 66%

choices.text: Higher sensitivity and the same specificity

questions.text: A standard test based on a serum marker is used to diagnose disease X. The distribution of the marker for this standard test in healthy and diseased patients is shown by the red curves in the graph below. A competitive company developed a new test based on the same marker. The distribution of the marker for the new test in healthy and diseased patients is shown by the black curves in the graph below. Compared to the old test, the new test has?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Higher sensitivity and higher specificity

 

Compared to the old test, the new test has higher sensitivity and higher specificity.

 

  • The black curves (new test) for healthy and diseased subjects are narrower and further separated, reducing overlap compared to the red curves (old test).
  • This means the ability to correctly identify both healthy (specificity) and diseased (sensitivity) individuals is improved because the marker levels are less likely to be misclassified.

  • Narrow distributions and greater separation increase the test's 

    discriminative power for both conditions

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with complaints of dry, itchy eyes and night blindness had the following ophthalmic finding as given in the image. What is the stage of vitamin A deficiency as per WHO classification?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Stage X3

questions.text: Which is the preferred anaesthetic technique used in a surgery for a patient with severe aortic stenosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) General anesthesia

 

  • Severe aortic stenosis (AS) → fixed cardiac output state.
  • These patients cannot tolerate sudden decreases in systemic vascular resistance (SVR) or preload, as it leads to profound hypotension and myocardial ischemia.
  • General anesthesia is preferred because:
    • It allows controlled induction, titration of anesthetic depth, and hemodynamic monitoring.
    • Vasopressors, fluids, and inotropes can be managed in a controlled setting.
    • Avoids the abrupt sympathetic blockade seen with neuraxial techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spinal anesthesia: Contraindicated in severe AS due to sudden, profound sympathetic blockade → rapid fall in SVR and preload → catastrophic hypotension.

 

Option C. Epidural anesthesia: Though more gradual than spinal, still causes sympathetic blockade and is risky in severe AS; not preferred.

 

Option D. Intercostal nerve block: Provides only regional analgesia, not sufficient as a sole anesthetic technique for major surgery in AS patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe aortic stenosis = avoid neuraxial anesthesia.

General anesthesia with meticulous hemodynamic monitoring is preferred.

 

Anaesthetic Considerations in Valvular heart Disease:

 

  • Maintain normal heart rate
  • Keep SVR low
  • Avoid myocardial depression
  • Maintain or slightly increase preload
  • Give prophylactic antibiotics
  • Most patients will tolerate spinal or epidural, provided intravascular volume is maintained.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of steps in investigating an epidemic?

 

1. Confirm epidemic existence

2. Verify the diagnosis

3. Formulation of hypothesis

4. Define the population at risk

5. Rapid search of cases
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2 → 1 → 4 → 5 → 3

 

Explanation of sequence:

 

1. Verify the diagnosis: Ensure clinical and lab confirmation to avoid misclassification.

 

2. Confirm epidemic existence: Establish that cases exceed expected baseline; rules out false alarm.

 

4. Define the population at risk: Finally, identify the community/group most vulnerable to guide control measures

 

5. Rapid search of cases: Case finding through active surveillance to measure extent of spread.

 

3. Formulation of hypothesis: Develop tentative explanation for source, mode, and risk factors.

questions.text: Identify the correct size and material of MRI compatible gas cyclinder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aluminium, Size E

 

  • MRI-compatible cylinders must be made of non-ferromagnetic material to avoid attraction by the MRI magnet.
  • Aluminium cylinders are standard for oxygen, nitrous oxide, and other gases in the MRI suite.
  • Size E is the commonly used portable cylinder for patient transport and emergency use in MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stainless steel, Size E: Ferromagnetic → unsafe in MRI.

 

Option B. Molybdenum steel, Size A: Ferromagnetic → unsafe in MRI.

 

Option D. Hard plastic, Size A: Not standard for gas storage; cannot withstand high pressure.
